instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
This board was liquid damaged cleaned with ultrasonic. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is at 8.2v
<SIGNAL>3V4_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.4
smc reset 3.4
smc onoff 3.4
ppvrtc 3.4

Testing with good audio board and cable, any advice? thanks

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
SMC doesn't work properly, or there is a problem on I2C battery bus.
I recommend to start reballing SMC.

Just in case, check diode mode and voltage at SCL/SDA lines of mentioned bus.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Diode mode on sda line was different than scleras, ultrasonic again was able to get me 8.4 on PPBUS, now an <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> issue i think <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> measures 0v. <TRANSISTOR>Q7950</TRANSISTOR> has all 4 voltages present, and the 6 parent lines of the pgood signals supplied by <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> are present, how would i go about checking if these lines are making the pgood signals for example if i have <SIGNAL>1V8_S0</SIGNAL> how would i know if <SIGNAL>1V8_S0_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is present since all the pgood signals measure 0v,

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: i am now realizing I'm missing <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> with no short there, what could cause this?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: so replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and connected <CAPACITOR>C7103</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7147</RESISTOR> since the test point was corroded, board does boot now but takes 300ma (20watts) that seems a bit high, it should be fine as long as it boots?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power
threads.message: was just some corroded test points this is solved thank you
